reviewText: I enjoyed this movie, but felt the screenplay was much too long...Julia Roberts exhibits her talented magic, as Liz Gilbert, a journalist who is spiritually and emotionally bereft. Roberts does a great job with capturing a confused, control freak, who is uncertain, generous in spirit, affable and vulnerable. Emerging from an ill matched marriage, to dating a more spiritually enlightened boy toy....Liz recognizes there is more to life and something very wrong with the men she chooses. So...with the amicable encouragement of her friends, she sets out to do something different! Viola Davis is very likeable as her BFF, a juggler supreme (super busy) life chaotically wonderful, supportive and self confident friendship. Liz makes an unexpected proposal to take a sabbatical from her normal life and journals her adventures along the way.The script was good, the cinematography great, and the director captured the essence of the woman and her companions. But the film was contradictory and just about 30 minutes too long. To say Liz was in an unhappy marriage bothered me...Liz was in an unhappy life (her own) and engages on an outer journey to places of inner discovery. She sets sail for Bali to find her journey's map, then on to Italy where she easily makes friends and revels in the wonders of a culture who is like a relaxed pair of jeans...you know, with the expandable waist? Liz even delivers a lecture on how unhealthy America is to women and their body image (gasp...muffin top stomachs!) She pledges to defy social mores to her newfound Swedish friend...to just "let go and live" while in the land of love and culinary delight. The problem is the camera then follows them to a boutique where they painfully, dully, try on several pairs of too tight pants, enduring the torture of having someone help them pull the zipper shut, whilst lying down for maximum flatbelly...ultimately buying another denim corset. It just doesn't compute. I guess I was hoping for more scenes of the history of Rome and more of the amazing food and drink...too much time on spaghetti (uhm, yeah, we have that here in the USA). Found myself wishing i could see the Sistine Chapel and more of the local, delights in bread, cheese, and pasta. Okay, so a letdown with the Italian sequence....the saving grace was the beautiful language and total lack of neuroses in the Italian culture,...at least within the confines of Liz's encounters.India was my favorite part of the story, it was humorous, capturing both the ruinous filth of the city and its collective devotion to prayer and enlightenment. Liz transcends her privileged, neurotic, monkey chatter thoughts by forming an intimate, platonic bond with another American devotee (played wonderfully by Richard Jenkins), who shares his story and prompts her (sometimes with an emotional cattle prod) to keep walking the inner path. Again though...too much time on watching someone meditate...uhm, hello? Its kind of like watching someone take a nap... not really engaging...unless you are going to throw in special effects. Our Liz was just not experiencing any significant inner plateaus during meditation, so no swirly whirly colors or visions...I would humbly suggest leaving some of this segment on the cutting floor.Back to Bali for the final installment, where Liz reconnects with her Yoda like shaman,"Ketut," who gives her tasks,throwing in niblets of common sense, with an adorable toothless grin and weird accent. To give the story credit, Liz (Julia Roberts) does her best work here....in particular, a scene on the beach where she portrays abject horror at the reality of being alone with the very vulnerable, and sensitive Javier Bardem I("Felipe")...a guarded, yet affable divorced gentleman she is growing very close to. Felipe is so diametrically different that he can easily see she is seeking a "champion," instead of the "boys" her history involves. Liz resists, of course, in her typical New Yorky stubborness of trying to find something on the exterior to "fix" her interior flaws. Many referenced the fortune cookie ending where she runs toward discomfort, risk, uncertainty and another chance at love. This time with someone who brings out the best in her...All in all, i would suggest this movie as a video rental...the movie theatre involved me eating too much popcorn and milkduds, during the parts that i would have left out. Cutting 30 minutes would have been way cool. Roberts, Jenkins, Bardem....all wonderful, and its admirable when anyone, from any class (even the well heeled upper, elite) takes the path less traveled...

reviewText: Julia Roberts returns to the screen in the much anticipated adaption of Elizabeth Gilbert's memoir "Eat, Pray, Love." No doubt this film will bring in many viewers due to the high-grossing memoir and what has been come to be called the Oprah effect. Oprah Winfrey has devoted TV shows to the book (one of her book club's selections) and recently a show was aired featuring Julia Roberts.Julia, as Elizabeth Gilbert, is thirty-something, married and working in New York as a writer. She comes to the realization that she feels nothing for the life she has created and her marriage ends. After a messy divorce and another failed relationship, Elizabeth embarks on a year round trip to Italy, India and Bali.In Italy, Elizabeth finds friendship and discovers how to relax and enjoy life. In India, her quest becomes more spiritual and she befriends Richard from Texas, played by Richard Jenkins. By example, Richard helps Elizabeth find forgiveness in herself. In Bali, she continues her spiritual pursuit while trying to find balance in life. Elizabeth becomes smitten with a Brazilian, played by Javier Bardem, and must decide if she can maintain her own individuality while falling in love.The story line is well written by Ryan Murphy (of Glee Fame) and Jennifer Salt and the acting is top notch as it should be with such a gifted cast. This will become a highly regarded film for Roberts, although not to the degree as her Oscar-winning portrayal of "Erin Brockovich." If any actors are noticed during award season, Richard Jenkins and Javier Bardem may have to compete with each other for supporting nods. The movie is beautifully film by Cinematographer Robert Richardson and will be a delight for anyone starved for beautiful scenery.Yes, this film could be classified as a chick film, but the lessons of a life well lived make the film more than just a nice interlude. It is a thoughtful film with messages that are deeper than any chick flick could ever hope to produce. This film will speak to anyone that has found times when they were in need of nourishment, inspiration and love."Eat Pray Love" is rated PG-13 and has a run time of 2 hrs. and 13 minutesEnjoy this review? reviewText: I borrowed this movie from a local library after hearing so many good comments about it. Perhaps we watched different movies, because I was was rather disappointed.The story revolves around Liz, a woman who visits a medicine man that reads her palm and tells her about the future. She decides to take his information to heart and begins making major changes in her life based on this knowledge. She begins by divorcing her husband, a man with lots of ambition but lacks focus. She finds comfort in the arms of a younger stage actor but shortly after realizes it was more of a rebound relationship than anything.In an attempt to figure out her priorities, she decides to take a year long trip through various locations hoping to find whatever it is she is missing. Her travels begin in Italy where she happens upon an English speaking Swedish woman at a local coffee shop. The two of them become friends and her social network in Italy begins expanding. Here she learns that sometimes doing nothing is alright, which is probably the best advice in the whole movie.Next she moves on to India to visit a spirtual leader she became interested in while dating the actor/yoga instructor. This seemed rather odd because it seemed like she wasn't all that interested in the leader while dating her boyfriend, so why would she travel around the world to attend her retreat in a different country? Here she is able to forgive herself for the divorce and any other wrongdoings in her life.The final locale is Bali where she reunites with the medicine man from the beginning and becomes his temporary assistant. He teaches her to find her balance in life, but ultimately tells her to forget the balance if she can find a love strong enough.Maybe the book is better because it can dwell more on tiny details and personal reflections. The movie, however, came across as a woman who had a pretty good life (successful author, large circle of friends, and a caring husband) who decides she wants more/something different. It seemed very much like a man's mid-life crisis taken to the extreme. At least with a mid-life crisis you might buy an expensive car or "toy", but Liz decides to leave everyone she loves behind in order to go on a self imposed mission to discover herself mentally and spiritually. For the average person this type of "retreat" would not be monetarily obtainable, but due to her success she is able to shirk all obligations for an entire year.

reviewText: Three stars for the scenic locations and the actors who did the best they could with what they were given.  This is watchable if you can suspend disbelief and fall in love with a selfish protagonist who doesn't deserve anybody's love.  That was one of the main problem's with this.  This is a woman who jumped into relationships she shouldn't have been in at the expense of others.  The issues she had in these relationships were never quite valid or clear.  I think it's probably a testament to many relationships these days where people just leave over tiny shreds.I didn't read the book so I imagine it was probably fantastic, but it's my understanding that some of what really happened to this author were adjusted in the movie.  If you can believe that the author's life was even more selfish than the way the movie portrays.  They actually had to tone it down a little or she would've really been vilified.For example: In the movie the Julia Roberts character wakes up one day from her marriage to the Billy Crudup character and decides she wants a divorce.  He presses her for a good reason which she's unable to divulge eloquently.  She then proceeds to fall into a passionate romance with a younger guy played by James Franco.  She goes through the same turmoil with him and leaves him setting off on a year journey to Italy, India and Bali to find herself.How it allegedly really went down was the real author cheated on her husband with this younger guy and left her husband for him.  That younger guy then cheated on her and left her in the end.  Now that should've been in the movie to teach one a lesson about how you treat others will come back to bite you.  I guess the filmmakers thought that the audiences would think she deserved it.  There is no way around her life.  It was all me-me-me and I-I-I.She spends a good portion in Italy eating her way through it and hanging with new friends.  Her friend complains that she needs to stop eating because she's gaining a few pounds.  The Julia Roberts character says, "Has a guy ever thrown you out or said something?" The friend says, "No."  Julia says, "Because he hit the jackpot he's with a naked woman."  Um - obviously she doesn't know much about what the man is REALLY thinking.All in all the story could've been worked a bit more to make her more of a likable protagonist.  The reason she's likable at all is because we're watching Julia Roberts who brings good things to the screen.  The message is hidden in there deep if you can get past all that.  And the scenery, acting and the way the film is shot keeps you afloat and interested.  There is a message in it that were all looking for enlightenment or answers or to be happy, but just don't use others or jump into relationships you're not ready for, because you then you just look like a dishonest loser.Julia Roberts makes this work - an unknown actress might not have been able to bring as much light as possible to such a negative character.  Does the protagonist find everything she's looking for?  The last half hour of the movie is the more intriguing, so it does end with a bang, but will you be able to hold out until you get there?  If there is any great line it's the man-friend she meets while praying in India.  He says, "To get to the castle - you got to swim through the moat."  He's full of soliloquy's to which she asks, "Do you always talk in bumper stickers?"  That was a line from the movie, "Postcards from the Edge" with Meryl Streep by the way.  Originality isn't easy these days if someone did it before you already.

reviewText: Inspiring!!Julia Roberts plays the role of a heartbroken divorced women who decides to travel to Italy, India, and Indonesia to find inner peace and balance. She goes on a 1 year journey traveling to these 3 countries searching for happiness.I was inspired by the quote given by Ketut: "In order to stay happy, you must always know where you are". If you do know your place in the journey of life, you will accept everything that happens to you and will have inner peace, eventually becoming happy. I believe this could simply be done by grabbing a piece of paper and write/draw on it your journey through life. Put on it life's basic elements such as success, love, family, spirituality, health...etc. See where you are. See the big picture. See which areas you need to improve and perfect. Hang this paper somewhere in the house and look at it everyday. Keep thinking about it, and I believe this is how you could achieve inner peace and balance.I heard people criticize this movie for being slow and sometimes boring. Well, the pace of the movie MUST be slow since its about achieving inner balance. You can't expect a fast paced movie about inner balance to be effective and received well. It has to be slow and need to take its time, just like the journey for the quest of happiness.Good movie, I highly recommend it.
summary: In order to stay happy, you must always know where you are

reviewText: Unfortunately, I think this movie watered down some of the themes of the book, and the character of Elizabeth Gilbert, to the point where it lost its depth. Part of what makes Elizabeth Gilbert likable in the book (and in my opinion she is likable, although I know some people don't feel that way) is that she is a keen observer and social commentator, in addition to being funny. Her sharpness, particularly her ironic insights, and her humor were entirely lost in this movie, leaving the character kind of insipid.Themes were watered down too. In the book, Elizabeth Gilbert's uncertainty about wanting kids, and the resentment she feels at social and familial pressure to do so, is more of a driver in the dissolution of her marriage than it is here. Perhaps the writers/producers felt that a mainstream audience couldn't handle questioning of social convention on that scale. As another example, in the book when Elizabeth collects money from her Western friends to help her Balinese friend Wayan purchase a house, the resulting problems spur an interesting analysis of cultural differences, and the problems inherent in trying to help someone from another social world. In the movie it's watered down to a feel-good success story (as is Elizabeth's romance there, while in the book it is considerably more complicated.) The India spiritual scenes are pretty watered down too - her insights are more self-helpy than spiritual.All that being said, I enjoyed watching Julia Roberts most of the time, and most of the supporting cast was very strong, especially Richard Jenkins and Javier Bardem. The shots of Italy, India and Bali were all lovely. So set your expectations accordingly, especially if you've read the book, and you can enjoy what there is to enjoy in this movie. If you want the true insights of the book though, just read it.
summary: If You Like Julia Roberts, Watch It, Otherwise, Just Read The Book

reviewText: The way they hyped up this movie and book - whose premise I really do like - I expected a nice piece depicting someone's journey through self-discovery. Instead, it turned out to be a trite two hour movie depicting the shameless self-indulgences and superficiality of a vain person on the quest for the elusive "finding yourself" mantra she undoubtedly read up upon in the self help aisle at Barnes and Noble. Because of how the character acted and was portrayed, the audience just never gets to identify and empathize with her and her "problems". For two hours you sit there and watch her whine about her life, how it is/was so unhappy and unfulfilled and what have you, but you never know why really. If the goal is to have the audience empathize with a character and identify with it, they have to know what's bothering them, be let in on their pain and unhappiness. That is what makes a great movie. The writers in this one seemed to want the audience to just take their word for it that she was unhappy and unfulfilled - despite all evidence to the contrary. Someone once said if the problem is in one's head, it still is a problem. But in this movie, we never get to see what that is - imagined or real. The worst thing a movie maker can do is create unrelateable characters.Julia Roberts did a lousy job and her character is both unlikeable and unrelateable. This movie is supposed to tell us that material things and money are not the source to happiness and that there are other sources of happiness unrelated to such external things. Yet the main character (Roberts) spends a year travelling around the world living in great places that cost a lot of money. Later on, this movie promoted a lip-gloss by Lnacome or something. Yeah...way to send a message about material things not mattering. They should have pointed out that trying to find yourself when you are broke is much harder to do. Luckily, Roberts in this movie didn't have to worry about that "tiny detail". One should be so lucky to have so much money that it is not worth mentioning anymore - even though it still is used to buy you all the sanity and self-discovery trips in the world.But it is not just that. The main character was annoying for other reasons as well. I mean her spiritual guide is a self-announced medicine man in Bali with amnesia. Yes amnesia, as in brain damage. She turns her life upside down because of the random crap he made up and told her, and then a year later when she goes back, to tell her "mentor" what she did, he doesnt even remember her!! It was hilarious. I thought they were kidding and that at this point the movie would take a turn; that her character would finally realize how immature and insane it was to do all those things to herself based on the random musings of a silly, old man who doesnt even know her. But NO. It stayed. That was it. Oh so conveniently, the shaman starts suddenly remembering her after she is about to burst into tears at the realization that she might have screwed up her life based on the words of a random, senile man.  That's deep.The movie went downhill from there at an alarming rate. I have never seen so much substance-deficiency and implausibility of both story and characters packed into two hours or so of narcissistic screen time for a middle-aged actress. The supporting characters were unlikable too and Julia Roberts just seemed too old and burned out for some of the "boys" she dated - like James Franco. They wanted to make it look like her relationship with Franco - which she started 5 minutes after her divorce by the way - didnt work out for other deep reasons, like she loved him, but it is obvious that it didnt work out cause she is too old for him and he a vacuous moron.  And then Javier Bardem. Obviously both of these people are on rebound, especially Bardem (who is 39 and has a 20 year old son but ok) but still after a couple of weeks of humping in the tropical hut, he confesses his ever endearing love for her like a starry-eyed 17 year old teenager. I seriously thought she knew better and would respond that she didnt feel the same way, that she didnt love him. But ta da, it turns out - despite all evidence to the contrary and what we see - she is in fact madly in love with him but (how original) is too scared to admit it cause she is afraid to get hurt. Yeah right. Could they have packed any more lame cliches into that?They could and they did because in the end, just like any other woman I guess, all she needed obviously to get out of her funk was love and riding off into the sunset (literally) with her man.Coming out of this garbage they tried to pass as a "wonderful journey" I figured that not only did I not get anything out of this movie and the supposed journey, but that obviously neither did the protagonist. Just as we never found out why she was really having a crisis and was unhappy, we also never find out why and how she got happy again. This movie is based on the premise that she lost her mojo and needed to find it, but looking closer it seems that she never had it. After that one year of travelling and exploring and meeting all these supposedly cool and enlightened people (quitters is more like it, see Bardem's character), she doesnt seem to have found more purpose in life than before. She doesnt look and act changed, enlightened or as if she had gained some insight into who she really is and what she really wants out of life. She spent a year travelling around, "hanging out" and having a good time and all she got to show for is a man. As expected, because by being a self-absorbed, spoiled brat who never had to do a hard day's work in life and doesn't listen to people you are not likely to gain insight into anything. Spiritually, she could have been Carrie Bradshaw's sidekick when she went into hysteria.In the end, she is exactly where she started: nowhere, drowning in her own superficiality and shallow-ness. The only exciting thing in her life will be a long distance relationship with Bardem between Bali and New York until she gets bored again and leaves, thinking that maybe the answers in life are to be found in the elusive wisdom of this one medicine man she read up upon on her last trip to the self help aisle - this time at Borders.
summary: Superficial Movie with an Insipid Plot Line and an Unsympathetic Protagonist. Awful Acting.
Title: Eat Pray Love

reviewText: What did I think? Well, "Eat Pray Love" is way too long. At two hours and 20 minutes, a film has to be more than the sum of its parts to be memorable. "Eat Pray Love" is not. We're never really convinced why Roberts as Liz Gilbert needs to indulge in a year off to travel the globe, and to go to the three specific places she visits. We know she wants to go back to Bali to meet again with an elderly spiritual adviser she meets there at the start of the film. We know she decides to go to an ashram in India to follow the teachings of a spiritual leader her vacuous post-divorce lover (James Franco; wasting his considerable skills)followed. Unfortunately, Franco was totaling uninteresting and not believeable as a man that Liz could really care for. Her character doesn't even seem to be particularly taken with the vocation of his particular ashram. We know she decides to go to Italy because, well, if given the chance, wouldn't we all go?  Thus begins the "Eat" part of her journey.Along the way, the solo Roberts as Gilbert (from now on, I'll just say "Liz")meets many and makes friends in every venue. During the journey, the crystallized reason for my enjoyment makes itself known at several turns...all involve touching small moments of friendship shared between Liz and someone who has come to mean a lot to her. It goes without saying that I go to see tear-jerker movies (my latest was the schmaltzy and wonderful "Letters to Juliet"), but they play and prey on their audience. Far more enjoyable are the movies which are subtle enough to create a lump in your throat, have your eyes well up, but allow you to flow through the moment on to the next scene. There are several times in the film that this happened to me, and those moments (and the cinematography and the incredible soundtrack) make me happy that I plunked down my $9.50.One of them involves Liz, who celebrates Thanksgiving with her adopted friends in Italy. As the dinner nears, it is discovered that the friend in charge of the turkey had not even defrosted it. The group enjoys the rest of the dinner, enjoys immensely the time they spend together, and then all nap through the night while the turkey cooks... waking in time to have it for breakfast. The scene where the camera pans across all the guests in "group nap" are charming, the reveal of the reason they stayed, the turkey, is one of those small chuckles and moments where you really feel the characters, because you have known people in your life who would have done exactly that with you.In India ("Pray"), Liz participates as a spectator at an arranged marriage between a young girl and her groom. During the ceremony, she pans back to her own wedding day, a wedding to Stephen (Billy Crudup) that ended in disaster when she abruptly determined that she could no longer pretend that she was happy with him, while pretending that their life together was enough for her. It wasn't. The poignancy of Liz' memories is when she imagines that they dance to the song that SHOULD have played at their wedding reception (the song that did play gives us another totally charming flashback, perhaps Crudup's only likeable moment in the movie). Into the mix comes the first 8 bars of "Harvest Moon", the ethereal love song that instantly makes you realize that Neil Young is a genius. I'm instantly transported by Young's imagery, and the lump comes back into my throat. I try hard to match my own memories of Harvest Moon with the dancing scene between Crudup and Roberts, but my own memories are more tangible and more connected to the song than the scene on film. However, the moment stands out as a reason for me to watch the film on DVD, and also wakes me up to how extraordinary and funky the soundtrack is; with two songs by Young, two by Eddie Vedder and some delicious Brazilian jazz, it is unforgettable.Also in India, the movie's best character, Richard from Texas (Richard Jenkins) makes an appearance, and from the casual nickname he gives Liz (based on her habit of eating everything in sight), "Groceries" , to the poignant scene in which he discloses the family tragedy that brought him on his own quest to India, Jenkins adds a friendship for Liz that feels more real than any that come first or follow later. Every scene that Jenkins is in is absorbing; you are left somewhat flat when he leaves and Liz is still in India, and you find yourself asking...why? Jenkins, a revelation in his role in the popular cable series, Six Feet Under, and a revelation as Theron's father in the bleak "North Country", has been wasting away, waiting for Hollywood to rediscover him. Looks like that wait is over.On to Bali, where the movie gets its biggest appeal; Javier Bardem as Felipe joins the film and finally Liz's quest doesn't seem so silly anymore. There is real chemistry between Roberts and Bardem, and the romance is so delicious that the lumps are back in my throat again. Also hard to beat are Bardem's moments on the phone and in person with the young actor who plays his son. His joy and sadness are so real. Liz's crusade to help a destitute mother in Bali by gathering donations from America also threatens to unravel me. Bali is so beautiful, Liz becomes so much more believable there, that the infinite 1.5 hours it took to get to this point don't matter so much anymore.And as the film wraps, I realize that, despite the harsh criticism from others, I appreciated Roberts' craft, her ability to capture you with facial expression, some of the supporting players, the beauty of her stops in the world, and the quirky soundtrack, far more than I ever enjoyed the book. Screenwriters Jennifer Salt and Ryan Murphy (who directed; also from "Glee", "Nip Tuck" and "Running With Scissors") may have left the audience stranded and muddled for long stretches, but they did manage to eke out a film that, in a way, was worth a look.
summary: Eat Pray Love - the film.  Worth a look!

reviewText: Is there a more wishy washy actress than Julia Roberts? I certainly haven't come across one. Perhaps the least deserving Best Actress Oscar winner in history, Roberts has relied on her 'charming smile' to get through roles without any discernible 'acting' going on. Case in point : "Erin Brokovich" and the woefully overwrought "My Best Friends Wedding". However, there are some of us who find Roberts' wide jawed smile rather disconcerting, unsettling and a little frightening, and lets just say this film does nothing to prove her case as an 'actress'.The book was bad enough (not many of you know that what happened to the author after the book was published and it is probably not going to make a very savory movie), but the film takes all of its vapid elements and multiplies it by a 100. The 'Pray' section for instance, is bewildering. Its difficult to ascertain what Roberts is going through when she closes her eyes on her meditative journeys, but on film these segments don't make any sense and don't reveal anything at all, except that a woman somewhere is closing her eyes. The director is especially gifted at sucking the life out of a scene, it has to be mentioned.The problem is with the script, as well as with Roberts over-confident performance. She might perhaps think that shes at a stage in her life where she can 'walk through' any role, but lets face it, the woman barely got through "The Mexican" without being upstaged by Pitt at every stage so she should really rethink her acting strategies. The worst part is the end, which neatly ties together her escapades and presents it as a more holistic episode of "Sex and the City" (should be seen to be believed). The supporting cast, often goodlooking but seldom talented, are totally wasted. The cinematography is beautiful but any of you with a home camera in any of these locations would find it hard to take a bad shot, so thats not saying much. Bali and Italy are pretty hard to tamper with on film. Sadly, they seemed to have captured the worst of India here, which is stereotypical of a film that tries to go the spiritual route (much like Kate Winslet in "Holy Smoke"). Javier Bardem, who is one of the worlds most nuanced actors is relegated to the role of a caricature here, while James Franco (whos lets face it is not going to win an Oscar for expressionism) plays an enlightened palm reader in Bali, which doesn't at all help matters. Billy Crudup is the best thing about this film, and at least he has the decency to only appear for a few minutes here and there.Bottom line, if you don't like Roberts' 'work', stay far, far away. Also, it might be of note that was a lot of eating going on in the film, and much less praying and loving. Well, at least they could keep their lunch down. Grab a pillow and pray for daylight if this is the mess you plan on renting tonight.An abominable film with no redeeming qualities.Two stars. Both out of generosity.

reviewText: I agree with one of the reviewers who wrote that some more easily relate to this film than others.  The film puts into words and images one take on midlife.  I wonder if it mirrors/symbolizes Margaret Mahler's stages of development.  Italy for symbiosis as highlighted with the merging with spaghetti scene.  India with separation from other/outer focus to an inward one via learning to meditate and Bali with independence and a return to the world with her stepping back into romantic relationships at a more mutual level.The Grimm's tale Duration Of Life also comes to mind:  The first thirty years is filled with a zest for life (Italy), the next thirty with grief and inner work (India or in the Grimm's tale:  the donkey and dog years) and the last phase (Bali or "the monkey years") with play and a generative contribution to society (a house was built for a healer).If this movie can be viewed as a metaphorical story for the midlife passage, Robert Bly's words come to mind when he said that fairy tales give us empathy and support to look inward to search for our core beliefs.On another level, this movie reminded me of Holland's Opus which was said to be a comfort movie for those who didn't realize their dreams - this movie for those who didn't experiecne the level of self fulfillment they would have liked or felt designed to experience.The scenes with Richard, who "speaks in bumper stickers," seem to serve as an image of a Boomer mentoring an Xer.  A colourful, fun and decent movie.

She didnt drone on verbally, but it was the constant state of unhappiness the character was in that was droning. It sucked my energy.Having done my own spritual quest these past 7 years, it was topped off last June by me breaking my leg, dislocating my knee cap, and tearing ligaments, my meniscus and finally placing cracks between where the joints meet. I've done my share of spiritual quest and I approached this as teaching me something - what i learned I wont share.  Having had to use crutches since June of 2010 (its now december), I've learned to be more in tune with the disabled. I rarely see them in grocery stores, the mall, anywhere. And its taught me that we're so caught up in our own world, that the only time we care about those who live a slower life that is parallel to our superficial lives, is aroudn Christmas.So having to sit through a movie where this woman has looks, a career, money, a handsome husband, numerous friends, is able to walk, eat, cook, essentially take care of herself, travel, and pretty much has more going for her except that she's a dreary soul is hard to sit through.I fast forwarded through alot of it. I'm a Pisces and a big fan of Javier Bardem and he shined like a jewel; thus the 3rd star.I wouldnt recommend eat pray love because it is a homage to egotistical maniacs who bemoan there existence and are not grateful for anything. reviewText: In 2006, a woman named Elizabeth Gilbert wrote a book called Eat Pray Love: A Woman's Search For Everything Across Italy, India, and Indonesia. This little book depicted her search for balance, and a better life. It was endorsed by the almighty Oprah, and therefore, millions of readers across the country, and across the world have been enlightened by her everywoman approach to spirituality, religion, and what needs to be done to live your best life.And, four years later, the film version is released. Naturally, Julia Roberts was selected to play the lead role. And, let me start out by saying, I was a huge fan of the book, and Julia Roberts was NOT who I had in mind to play Gilbert. I saw someone like Kate Winslet, or Anne Hathaway in the lead role. I thought that with Roberts playing the lead role, the story would be transferred from a deep, spiritual journey, to just another Julia Roberts movie.I was pleased to discover that I was wrong in these thoughts. Julia Roberts is a fabulous actress, and like any fabulous actress, she makes you believe that this part couldn't have been played by anybody else. She embodies the role, it's obvious that she spent months, perhaps even a year, getting into character. She is so reminiscent of the Elizabeth Gilbert character. After watching this film, it's clear that she was the obvious choice for the role.In the film, Liz Gilbert (Roberts) is a seemingly happy married woman. She has everything a modern American woman is supposed to want: husband, beautiful home, great friends, terrific job, etc. She discovers that that's not all it takes to make one happy. She divorces her husband (Billy Crudup), and starts to date an actor (James Franco) from a play that she wrote. She finds a beautiful human connection with him, but realizes that even he's not what she really needs.She breaks it off with him, quits her job, and decides to take a journey around the world, that would last one full year. This journey would start in Italy, where she would get in touch with her abandoned love for food, then moving to India, where she would find religion, and then to the Indonesian island of Bali, where she would try to find love again.A colorful array of supporting actors make this film what it is. Viola Davis plays Gilbert's BFF Delia, who is tragically underused, but she is a kind of voice of reason for the wishy-washy emotions of our heroine. Javier Bardem was the obvious choice to play her Indonesian lover Felipe, who has undeniable chemistry with Roberts. Richard Jenkins plays a man who Gilbert meets in India, who acts as sort of a confidante to our main character.The heart of this film, however, lies in the breathtaking cinematography, and beautiful soundtrack. Director Ryan Murphy, of Glee, and Nip/Tuck fame, treats this better than he did his previous adaptation Running With Scissors. It's directed with love, and it follows the book as well as can be expected. He fits alot of gorgeous architecture, and beauty into the massive scope. Each frame is a postcard, and makes the viewer long to take a journey like this at some point in their life. It also is very resonant on an emotional level. It makes you believe that even the most cynical person can find happiness if they allow themselves to.In the end, this isn't a romantic comedy. This isn't a chick flick, it isn't even a `Julia Roberts movie', it's a loving adaptation of an admired memoir. It will surely satisfy fans of the book, as well as fans of Julia Roberts. But, you don't need to be a Roberts fan to appreciate what this film has to offer. Its message is universal, beautiful, and breathtaking. See it.
summary: Just what I wanted in a film adaptation of a favorite memoir.

reviewText: The striking tone in the movie was Julia Robert's vicious personality. You could not help but believe that was her own biography, or the same replicated lifestyle of women getting lost in the underworld of acting to please others. The movie narrates the trauma inflicted on actors when acting stops and real living begins. Jane Fonda moved to France, sought spirit in India, peace in Vietnam, but at the end, Fonda ruined every thing in her life to return to the madness of Hollywood. When Hollywood has no need for a senile Fonda. Julia Roberts trailed Fonda in her agonizing loneliness.The eating part was disturbing as well. The Robert must travel to the carbohydrate kitchens of Italy to enjoy the lazy and purposeless life of Italians. In Italy, every one eats, talks, and sleeps. The movie displayed three scenes of the disgusting tradition of poking passerbys in their rear ends by locals with impunity. The assaulted targets have no option but to express anger and disdain, to no avail.Praying in India sounded odd also since all outsiders have no clue what they were reading, hearing, or doing. Intensive course in spirituality did little to reverse Hollywood's deep seated demons. India's spiritual setting sounded like self punishment by isolation and preoccupation as an escape from one's own vices. In comparison to the fat, lazy, and uncivil Italians, the Indians ate less and bothered no foreigner.Love was also missing all along. In America, the writer (Julia Robert) admits to have spent all her life between guys. In Italy, most women were fat, happy, senile, but married for eternity. India was entirely love-free, and spirit-rich. In Bali, love was of the American brand, induced by liquor, dancing, and physical attraction minus chemistry or character.Walking out of the movie, one could not resist the obnoxious and self absorbed role of Julia Robert contrasted with the laid back Italian women whose common sense belongs to the dark ages.
summary: Jane Fonda revisited. Soul rearching would have been a better title.

reviewText: Like many movies before it, EPL is a film about "finding one's self".  Fortunately there are better examples than this story of a woman (Julia Roberts) who realizes her marriage is a sham, gets a divorce then shacks up with a young actor (James Franco).  Na, this doesn't feel right either, so she puts her belongings in storage (what no furniture?) and heads out for a year long journey to Italy, India and Bali.  It's hard to feel too sorry for her.  How many of us could take a sabbatical like that?  She can, as she is a successful writer and speaker about the human condition.  The film is beautifully shot but seems to lack the heart and soul and emotional depth we chick flick types look for.  The movie isn't a total failure however.  The acting is fine; the music is really good, ranging from some nice Brazilian stuff to vintage Neil Young.  The best parts of the movie are where Liz (Roberts) writes her letters or otherwise narrates her feelings.  These are beautifully written, I suspect straight from Elizabeth Gilbert's book.
summary: The film lacks heart and soul but the written letters are beautiful

reviewText: You guessed it, not my turn to pick the movie. In the past this worked for the best, getting exposed to good movies I would not had picked otherwise. This time though I was itching for a magazine well before the movie was halfway through.A woman in mid-life crisis ends her unfulfilling marriage to her equally immature and directionless husband for no other major reason. The divorce is messy with a lot of guilt to be distributed around. A brief (cougar-)affair ends equally badly so she embarks in a year-long journey to redefine herself.The journey starts from Italy where apparently she learns to appreciate life's little pleasures and how to enjoy them guilt-free. This part made me hungry for good Italian pasta with fresh tomato sauce and basil but little else. Having said that I have been to Naples and (with all due respect to my Napolitano friends), one can find much better-tasting pizza in New York.By the way, when someone decides to accept her body no matter its imperfections and goes shopping for larger jeans, she does not then proceed to force the zippers of ...smaller sizes.India was next and it was a disaster. The guru she has traveled so far to meet is visiting the US and her disciples run her ashram like something between a hostel and a Scientology sweat-shop. She receives no enlightening guidance except some overused bromides from a Texan in his post-alcoholic guilt trip.I love Indian culture and have a great respect for Indian people. However, unlike SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE, this movie will not make you want to visit this mesmerizing country.Finally, Bali where she meets again a toothless old medicine-man/palm reader. She copies some notes; she runs a short but effective charity fund; and she finds lust/love in the sad eyes of a Brazilian divorcee. What did she learn in the previous year: apparently nothing because she is about to run away from that relationship as well. Will she? Well, at that point point I could not care less.I gave it 2-stars solely for the travelogue images.

reviewText: I was hesitant to see the film, knowing how Hollywood can take a good book and ruin it.  I was also dismayed at the choice of Julia Roberts as Liz Gilbert.  Having read the book, I had a hard time imagining Roberts portraying the very intelligent, honest, and sincerely soul-searching Gilbert.  I can think of a number of finer actresses who would have been more convincing and perhaps contributed to a better film.However, it seems that the fault is not all with Roberts.  I think the director must have played a major role in diminishing the book.  Still, we have to thank him for bringing it to life.  It is, by the way, visually gorgeous.One of the major faults of the script is the way it didn't adequately show the depths of Gilbert's despair in the beginning.  It  actually portrayed her husband as a pleasant-enough guy which is contrary to the message in the book. The film almost makes it seem that she's leaving him just because he doesn't want to go to Aruba with her.  No wonder so many people who haven't read the book slam this character as empty, spoiled, whiney and selfish.  As another reviewer mentioned, it is her acute despair that propells her to make her amazing journey.About half way through the film, I overcame my dislike of Roberts.  It was, coincidently, in the India segment, about the time Gilbert began to face her own problems and discovered a new depth in herself.  Roberts rose to the occasion and showed the new maturity beautifully.  The scene where she offers her "gift" to the newlywed Indian girl is quite moving.Richard Jenkins is fun as the Texan she meets at the Ashram, although I did find his "confession" scene a little over-the-top.James Franco as the actor didn't really impress me either...maybe because he mumbled most of his lines, preferring a lot of loopy facial expressions to portray his ardor.The actors in Bali were good, especially the fellow who played the wise man.  He is almost worth the price of admission.  I agree with another reviewer that the interaction between Gilbert and Wayan, the medicine woman, was given short shrift.  But the importance of the Bali sequence was that this was where she found "love."  Bardem plays the charming Brazlian entrepreneur who overcomes her fear of love beautifully.  He's a little shaggy but that doesn't detract from his immense charm. He's perfect for the part--seems truly to be a man who is worth her attention, as opposed to the two she left behind.I thought the Amazon review was excellent except for the conclusion that the story was more escape than spiritual.  To me, this came across as a remarkable tale of a genuine spiritual voyage.  The fact that it has a happy ending shows that she did the hard work, faced her own inner demons and came out a better, happier person, more willing to love and to be loved. Doing this intense inner work is not self-indulgent or escapist; it's very hard and I commend Gilbert and anyone who endeavors to undertake it. It is hardly escapist.  I can only guess that people who haven't done this kind of inner jouney have no inkling of what they're missing.  Too bad...I hope this film helps some of them to wake up!Despite the flaws of the film, I give it five stars for it's theme.

reviewText: I remember turning on "Oprah" when Liz Gilbert was on a few years back discussing the book version of Eat Pray Love. I could stomach about 10 minutes of her whining about how her privileged, upper-middle-class lifestyle just wasn't fulfilling her and how she had to give it up for a year to find herself. She had a good husband, she had a good job, she had a new home that she decorated just the way she wanted it, and yet, dang it all, it just wasn't quite enough. Why is that? Why is that? Ah, yes. Because she's selfish. And how cool is it that her lifestyle afforded her the luxury of finding herself during a year of travel to exotic places. Why, we all should do it. What the heck are we waiting for?I can recall that at the end of this "Oprah," Liz was telling us that we can all have our own "Eat Pray Love" moment, even if it's just a ten-minute break in a quiet corner of our bedroom, away from the chaos of the kids, work, husband, and the bills. I don't know about you, but taking a break while sitting for ten minutes in a friggin' chair with the door locked while my sticky-fingered kids are pounding on said door, wondering why Mommy locked herself in her room, isn't quite the same thing as taking a year off of my life to travel to three exotic places most of us can only read about. Maybe it is the same, because enlightened Liz says so and she seems to have all the answers.Julia Roberts, I believe, tried to make Liz appealing/relatable, but who can relate to a woman like this? I mean, who can walk away from her marriage because her husband's, what, simply a nice guy with not enough ambition to satisfy her needs? Who can relate to a person who has the luxury of dropping out of life for a year to travel to Italy, India, and Bali? Who can relate to a woman who turns down a guy like James Franco (I know he was supposed to be a younger man, but I found Franco and Roberts to be a way awkward couple) or Javier Bardem (come on now).And what is it that makes Eastern religions so much more mystical and alluring to people looking to "find themselves" than, say, Christianity or Judaism? (I guess calling it "meditating" instead of "praying" is the key.)Well, there are some pluses to this film. The cinematography of Italy is a big plus. (India apparently is too harsh a reality to photograph much of, so all we see are interior shots and an occasional cow near a squatting boy--I guess this is supposed to symbolize the country's poverty, which is ignored throughout the film.) And the film is good for a two-hour escape from reality, because, after all, escapism is what it's all about.
summary: Eat (till your jeans don't fit), Pray (but call it the more exotic "meditating"), Love (yourself)

reviewText: To put it simply, Eat Pray Love is a movie with beautiful scenery and about a woman who feels unfulfilled and seeks the help of people who seem to be experts on how to live life. Don't expect anything too deep. The writers expected viewers to have read the books and so they don't give us much information as to what exactly causes her to feel such a lack of passion in the first place. Italy (Eat) provides a tourist's dream: good food, good friends, and basically the overall message of living a life of pleasure. India (Pray) is the more serious and the more interesting story here is not about Liz but of the Texan and young Indian girl we see in the movie. The message is meditation and learning to clear the mind. Bali (Love) is where it comes full circle so to speak. She learns that she is finally ready to love again. Once you love yourself, you can be free to dive into the chaos of loving someone else. The messages presented in the movie are things everyone already has heard which is why some other reviewers call it "shallow" which I can understand. The acting is so great that they bring more character to the screen than what the script gave them [excluding the husband and the actor, the script gave those characters no hope]. I picked Eat Pray Love so that I could watch someone do what I have always wanted...to go to a foreign place and immerse myself fully into the culture and learn some kind of lessons that could be applied in my everyday life. So despite the movie's lack of true depth I thoroughly enjoyed it and would watch it again, just to sit and daydream and wish I could go far away as well.

reviewText: `Eat, Pray, Love' is an average film with a decent message and as I haven't read the book I can only review this film based on it's own merits, rather than comparing it to the message the book imparts.This film follows Liz (Julia Roberts) after she divorces her husband and travels to Italy, India and Bali as she tries to find some meaning in her life.  She learns about herself, makes some friends and has some amazing experiences, like travel will often do for anyone.I hate to say it, but this film is overly sentimental and whilst the basic message is a good one (being true to yourself and finding god within you) this film feels like it has to spell it out for you as if you are stupid and can't grasp the message being rammed down your throat at every turn.  This may sound harsh and I don't mean it to, as this is perfectly watchable and entertaining, but I don't know why film makers feel the need to dumb things down to such a degree that they almost insult the viewers intelligence.  The `meaningful' voice-overs spelling things out particularly started to grate by the end of the film.Roberts is pretty average in this film and Bardem is probably the best of the actors here.  Saying that, Richard Jenkins is very good as well and deserves a mention.  The direction is ok and is certainly very glossy and shows the countries off to spectacular effect (like a glorified tourist advert for each destination), but it lacks a certain depth and, like the film in general, it feels rather superficial.Don't get me wrong, this film is good enough and certainly has something to offer, but it has no nuance and isn't as `deep' as it likes to think it is.  The book may be a whole lot better, but judging this is on it's own merits I'd say this is a good but not great film and it is worth a watch; just don't expect too much and you should be fine.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: Title: Eat, Pray, LoveDirector: Ryan MurphyWriter: Ryan Murphy, Jennifer SaltCast: Julia Roberts, Javier Bardem, James Franco, Viola Davis, Richard Jenkins, Billy Crudup, Tuva NovotnyYear: 2010A memoir is the exact opposite of a screenplay. A memoir is full of inner monologue, emotion, endless stories that take place over a great amount of time and it's all told in a first person narrative. A screenplay has to be short, concise, pure dialogue and contain very little obvious emotion (thats for the actors to interpret). So when a memoir is chosen to be adapted into a feature film it's quite the challenge. You have to stay true to the events and the person telling them but you also have to work within the constraints that a feature film demands. This is what writer/director Ryan Murphy (Running with Scissors, TV's "Glee") was faced with on his film Eat, Pray, Love.Elizabeth Gilbert's classic memoir of self discovery, spirituality and love by traveling to Italy, India and Bali is a wonderful book full of wit, wisdom and meaning that can be appreciated by anyone; though only about 2/3s of that is translated to film. In any adaptation, whether it be novel, comic or memoir, there is one thing that I personally want to see faithfully portrayed: the themes (think Marry Harron's adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis' American Psycho). Of course there are going to be adjustments to the narrative and characters due to the difference of artistic mediums, but thankfully Murphy pulls it off with his film. He is able to find the right balance of addition and subtraction to properly honor the source material yet also create a satisfying stand alone film.The film beings with Liz (Julia Roberts, Erin Brockovich) struggling with her unfulfilled life and loveless marriage to Stephen (Billy Crudup, Watchmen). Divorce proceeds and so does a rocky rebound relationship with David (James Franco, Milk). Living an aimless life without passion and against the better judgment of her best friend Delia (Viola Davis, Doubt), Liz embarks on a round the world journey to reconnect with pleasure (eat), her spirituality (pray) and self esteem (love). Along the way she meets many 'the wise stranger' (Richard Jenkins, The Visitor; Javier Bardem, No Country for Old Men) and visits some of the most beautiful places on earth.Sure, this may sound like a seriously sappy and contrived film, but in all honesty, it's not. Murphy never lets the film dip into melodrama and handles his story with a smooth, confident hand. While he could have taken some of the more edgier parts of the book (ex: Liz's severe depression) to the screen, the movie ends up being cleaner and crisper and all the more fun without it. The picture is meant to inspire the audience to have fun, to connect and to live life, if the darker issues were included the message could have missed the mark. Murphy accomplishes this sense of euphoria visually and ascetically with the help of master cinematographer Robert Richardson (Inglourious Basterds). The shots of Italy, India, Bali, and heck, even New York, are so georgous that if you can't afford to take a vacation this year, a ticket to Eat, Pray, Love will do the trick.What ties the film together is, of course, the luminous Roberts. She is, of course, a bon a fide movie star and this material is something that she can easily use to showcase her talents. She is backed by a terrific and believable supporting cast of Hollywood stars and native Italians, Indians and Balinese actors- all equally great.Eat, Pray, Love may not be a groundbreaking motion picture, but it's certainly a film that is enjoyable. It engages you emotionally and to me, that is the first and most important thing I look for in any film. It might not be the most faithful adaptation fans of the book were hoping for (and how could it have been?), but on it's own it's a picture with an easy charm and it's a harmless way to spend two and a half hours.Rating: B
summary: A faithful adaptation of a beloved memoir

reviewText: Eat, Pray, Love is a true story about a writer who leaves her husband because she's overcome with the feeling that her life doesn't fit and isn't a real reflection of herself. She seeks escape in a younger man, doesn't find it, then decides that she may have better luck by doing a yearlong adventure in Italy, India, and Indonesia. Through those adventures she finds love and happiness again.I have mixed feelings about the movie. I read the book and felt it was a self-indulgent pity party. I didn't expect much from the movie, but wanted to give it a chance.CONS:Julia Roberts is horrible. I am not a Roberts fan, but seeing her in this was agony. I am so over her. She can't act. Period. She is the same in everything. Was this Erin Brockovich Goes to Italy or Julianne Porter (from My Best Friend's Wedding) Shacks Up? She looked depressed most of the time. When she lit up, it was a huge contrast, but that rarely happened. The only way I knew that she had transformed into a happy person was when the Balinese man (Ketut) said so.The pace was REALLY fast. I knew that there had to be a lot left out in order to cover adventures in three countries and give it a set up as well, but this was lightning speed. It didn't give a chance to really get the flavor of each location or how she was changed by the experiences there. We are just given dialog that tells us what happened. The segues from place to place were abrupt too.The ah ha! moments didn't translate to film. The first one was, "Go to bed, Liz." That wasn't illuminating to me in the book either, but I could see how she thought it was. In the film, it was as if God was not listening to her. All of the big turning points in the book were lost in the movie.It's unrelatable. It feels like a fantasy. "Normal" people just don't cry over nothing, run off for a year, forget all their friends, and come back happy. I think that is the big message of the movie and that falls flat...unless that is your fantasy.PROS:Despite all I just said, I actually "got" that her inner/outer journey was transformative. Maybe that was because I read the book. Maybe it's because I lead sacred travel tours and have experienced that same growth myself. Some of the things that may have seemed trite and New Age resonated with me. (Maybe because I'm trite and New Age? lol)The scenery was the big winner. As a world traveler myself, I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE seeing new places. The locations weren't just shot as background. They were characters in the movie! That was very effectively done. Of the three locations, I have only been to Rome, but it IS everything you see and more!I hate when people can't review a product for what it is instead of comparing it to the book because often, I haven't read the book. Sorry for doing that to you. If you haven't read the book and are wondering whether to try it out, my advice is, if you like Roberts, the Hollywood formula and exotic locales, you will probably like it. If you want meaning, logic and good acting, forget it. :)

reviewText: [NOTE: I drastically edited my review. The essence is above the line. The addition is below. I hope this new/edited review at least helps people stop and think.]You've probably read the raves about the scenery and food. Yes, they're great. And probably seen that Julia did what she could with this role. Again that's true. Also that she plays a main character who leaves her life behind to find herself. At least, that's what the movie is supposed to be.But all I saw was that Liz had a great life, but thinks that friends, family, and relationships are disposable. Financial security is something to be discarded on a whim. Just go ahead and throw everything away, then focus on yourself, yourself, yourself.Everyone else in this movie had it harder than Liz did. Her husband was willing to talk things over with her, but she refused. Then she dove straight into the arms of another man, dumping him too when she didn't feel fulfilled enough. All around the world, Liz found people whose lives were more difficult than hers. Did it give her pause to think?Nope. All Liz learned is that she needs to be nicer to herself, to find people who make her happy, and that she can love others and herself at the same time. *gasp*After finding this revelation, does Liz make any effort to repair the trail of shattered relationships she left behind? Does she realize that all relationships take work, maintenance, and tender loving care?Nope. Instead, Liz just rides off into the sunset, finally knowing who she is and what she wants. Keep looking for your identity until you discover who you are. Then live happily ever after, as if relationships either work or they don't, like some kind of childhood fairy tale.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------But wait! This is supposed to be an inspirational movie! A movie that shows a brave woman's journey as she travels around the world determined to find herself. Ok, great, I get that.Now picture a MAN in this role. A MAN who divorces his rich wife and leaves all his friends because he isn't satisfied and doesn't know who he is anymore. A MAN who goes from woman to woman, feeling unloved by any of them.A MAN traveling around the world, eating until he bursts out of his clothes. A MAN learning to be nicer to himself. A MAN caring only about himself, until he realizes he can love others and himself, and then finally lets himself fall in love again.Is this STILL a beautiful movie?

reviewText: The story begins with Liz failing out of two relationships, well aware of how each got the way it was but baffled as to why. So, in order to find herself, she goes looking in places she's never been.The 'Eat' part of the story take place in Rome, where Liz discovers the wonder of 'dolce far niente' - the sweetness of doing nothing. Except that it's not nothing, it's full involvement in the little things of each moment, and in turning the biological demand for fuel into a kind of making love. The mouth-watering, full-screen shots of pasta, melon, turkey, and more show just what there is to love, including a drumstick moment that approaches the one inTom Jonesfor sensuality. (In truth, this segment of the movie made me ashamed of the bland drink and stale popcorn I had inflicted on myself at the theater's concession stand.)Since I'm not in the "chick flick" demographic, the next two passages didn't do so much for me. Liz's next stop was India, where I hoped the culinary passion would play out among the complex flavors of India's cuisines. Although Liz brought a healthy appetite with her, the 'Eat', 'Pray', and 'Love' segments of the movie didn't overlap, and India marked the transition from 'Eat' to 'Pray'. As in any good spiritual journey, Liz encoutered new teachers during this phase, and not the ones she had expected. For reasons known only to Liz, the time in India came to its end, and she moved on to Bali and 'Love'. I was happy to see that 'Love' took many forms, and not just the mandatory romance.I'm more of a guy movie kind of guy, but I see my wife's movies almost as often as she sees mine. As estrogenic cinema goes, my taste tolerated this one quite well - but I'd come back to the 'Eat' portion of the movie any time. Four stars: not necessarily because of how it matched my preferences, but because how well it seemed to do what it wanted to.-- wiredweird, reviewing the release to theaters

reviewText: This movie is BRILLIANT. It was exactly what I needed when it first came out, and it still is.Ignore the bad reviews; people judge things they don't understand. This is not a romantic comedy, so while it can be funny and romantic, that is not its purpose. It's the hero's journey from myth, but with a female hero.Nonattachment and choosing your own thoughts, subjects covered during her trip to India, are the key to happiness and are being taught in every spiritual discipline. Nonattachment is what spiritual teachers are teaching students right now. It's ironic in the best way that the attachment she ultimately had a hardest time giving up was her new dedication to nonattachment! She was terrified of wanting something again, and making a commitment.She is not selfish for choosing the life she wants. As women we're taught that we're bad people if we don't dance to everyone else's tune. I thought it was the bolder choice doing what they did, maintaining the first husband's personality from the book, and making him not a bad guy. It was no one's fault, it just wasn't working.I've been in her position, praying for something, anything, a way up off the floor. And education is almost always the answer. Yes, the fact that the character seemed to have a lot of money made her trips a lot easier but that's not a reason to be completely prejudiced against her. Starting with physical indulgence in Rome, exploring the power of pleasure, then turning completely spartan in India and concentrating only on the spirit, she had to find out if it was possible to do both -- to live in the modern world, enjoy herself, and maintain the spiritual life she needed. She got both, and the right man, in Bali.This movie is perfect for anyone having hard times, someone exploring spirituality, especially meditation, Eastern religions, or simply anyone who really wants to travel. It hit me on all fronts. Watch it if you want to know more about having a larger life.
Title: Eat Pray Love

Title: Eat Pray Love

reviewText: I am sad to see such negative "catty" reviews posted. It seems that most reviewers just don't "get it" and thus were not truly open to the message of the film. Yes, Liz is successful, beautiful, seems to have everything, made her choices...as we all have and do. I do not know what to say to convey the frustration I feel with a society who largely fails to see humanity and truth over the superficial and greed. This film is a HUGE message to all of us who are crabby (and as a result claim to call a judgement, "review"), unsatisfied, confused, lost, frustrated, who continue to do the same things and expect different results...etc, etc, etc. Liz Gilbert's experience is a shared and universal one regardless of one's background or current worldly status. The film if you pay attention to the woman instead of the things around her, is inspirational in many ways. I am not rich in material goods, I've never had the privilege of owning a home in this country, and currently I do not have my health, but I know what it's like to work like crazy for empty and meaningless dreams to discover something more...search for growth. I applaud Liz's courage, abandonment of all she knew...step by step...to travel another road less traveled only to discover she was the love she was looking for all along. If only we all had such courage and optimism and fortitude, we'd be a much more kinder and compassionate society and world.
